message.content: Solanum mauritianum, commonly known as bugweed or kawakawa, is a shrub native to South America and widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions. It can grow up to 10 meters tall, with a woody stem and branches covered in thin, pointed leaves. The leaves are dark green, glossy and have serrated edges, with white to pale lilac trumpet-shaped flowers clustered at the ends of the branches. The fruit is a small, green to yellowish berry, containing numerous small, round seeds. Solanum mauritianum is considered a weed in many parts of the world and is used in traditional medicine to treat a variety of ailments, such as fever, coughs, and skin infections. Its latex is believed to have insecticidal properties and is used in organic farming practices.
